The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?

Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{book | title=Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens) | image = Last Song 1974.png | author=[[J.R.R. Tolkien]] | illustrator=[[Pauline Baynes]] | publisherUK=[[Unwin Hyman]] | publisherUS=[[Houghton Mifflin]] | date=Poster: [[26 November]] [[1974]]
Book: December [[1990]] | format=Poster; hardcover; paperback | pages=32 | isbn=0044407289 | precededby=[[The Road Goes Ever On: A Song Cycle]] {1968) | followedby=[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Pearl, and Sir Orfeo]] {1975) }} '''''Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)''''' is a poem written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]. It is sung by [[Bilbo Baggins]] at the [[Grey Havens]] as he is about to leave [[Middle-earth]]. Chronologically this places it at the very end of ''[[The Return of the King]]'', the last volume of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'', although it was written later than the books and never included in them. The poem first appeared as posters (60×40 cm) in November [[1974]], illustrated by [[Pauline Baynes]], published by Allen & Unwin. The first book edition was published in [[1990]], illustrated by the same artist. It is a 32-page full colour picture-book, each double page containing two lines of the poem, with almost fifty of Baynes's paintings. The poem was included in the second edition of ''[[The Road Goes Ever On (book)|The Road Goes Ever On]]'', set to music by [[Donald Swann]], in [[1978]]. ==Background== It was originally a composition in Old Norse, entitled ''Vestr um haf'' ("West over sea"), written as early as 1920s. In [[1968]], after [[Joy Hill]], Tolkien's secretary, rediscovered it in a pile of books, Tolkien gave it to her as a gift for her assistance in the setting up of his new office. After Tolkien's death in [[1973]], Hill showed the poem to [[Donald Swann]], who liked the poem so much that he set it to music and included it in the second edition of ''[[The Road Goes Ever On (book)|The Road Goes Ever On]]'' in [[1978]].{{RGEO|Bilbo}} The poem was also illustrated by [[Pauline Baynes]], and published as a poster on [[26 November]] [[1974]]. The song was included in the BBC Radio 4 adaptation of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' (1981), with music by Stephen Oliver. The first verse is chanted by John Le Mesurier as Bilbo, the second omitted, and the third sung by a boy soprano. In 1996 the song was recorded by the [[Unquendor|Dutch Tolkien Society]] band [[The Hobbitons]], with permission from the [[Tolkien Estate]], for their CD ''J.R.R. Tolkien's Songs from Middle-earth''.{{webcite|website=[http://web.archive.org/web/20021210152658/http://home.wxs.nl/~hobbiton/home.html The Hobbitons] (via [http://www.archive.org Internet Archive]) |articlename=Our CD|articleurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20021207123849/home.wxs.nl/~hobbiton/OURCD.HTM|accessed=27 May 2014}} The copyright of the poem was given by Tolkien to Hill together with the poem itself. Upon her death in 1991, Hill gave the copyright to the [[Wikipedia:Order of the Holy Paraclete|Order of the Holy Paraclete]]. Baynes's illustrations for ''Bilbo's Last Song'' were not included in the bequeathing to the Order, but were given the [[Wikipedia:Williams-Exeter Programme at Oxford|Williams-Exeter Programme at Oxford]] upon her death in 2008.{{webcite|author=[[Wayne G. Hammond]], [[Christina Scull]]|articleurl=http://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/mythsoc/conversations/messages/25132|articlename=Bilbo's Last Song and the Order of the Holy Paraclete (message 25132)|dated=7 March 2014|website=Mythsoc|accessed=16 March 2014}} ==The poem== '''Bilbo's Last Song''' (At the Grey Havens) Day is ended, dim my eyes, but journey long before me lies. Farewell, friends! I hear the call. The ship's beside the stony wall. Foam is white and waves are grey; beyond the sunset leads my way. Foam is salt, the wind is free; I hear the rising of the Sea. Farewell, friends! The sails are set, the wind is east, the moorings fret. Shadows long before me lie, beneath the ever-bending sky, but islands lie behind the Sun that I shall raise ere all is done; lands there are to west of West, where night is quiet and sleep is rest. Guided by the Lonely Star, beyond the utmost harbour-bar I'll find the havens fair and free, and beaches of the Starlit Sea. Ship, my ship! I seek the West, and fields and mountains ever blest. Farewell to Middle-Earth at last. I see the Star above your mast! ==Publication history and gallery== File:Last Song 1974.png |1974 poster File:Last Song 1990 1992.png ‎|1990 hardcover & 1992 paperback File:Last Song 1992 private.png ‎|1992 private print File:Last Song 2002.jpeg ‎|2002 hardcover File:Last Song 2012.jpeg ‎|2012 paperback * [[George Allen and Unwin]], poster ([[1974]]) * [[Unwin Hyman]], hardcover ([[1990]]), pp. 32. ISBN 0044407289 * Red Fox/Arrow Books, paperback ([[1992]]) ISBN 0099910209 * Albert House Press, pamphlet in card cover ([[1992]]) * Hutchinson hardcover ([[2002]]), pp. 32. ISBN 0091884888 * [[HarperCollins]] paperback ([[2012]]), pp. 32.
